ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course offers a great introduction to one of the greatest novels of all time. It balances close reading with broader historical, thematic, and formal considerations. There is a high level of student participation. It is hard work (readings are substantial), but definitely one of the most rewarding courses I have taken at Yale.
This course is a great exploration of an incredible novel - very satisfying for anyone who loves the humanities, french literature of the modern arts.
Close reading skills; facility considering same text from many critical perspectives.
I spent a wonderful semester with the greatest work of literature I've ever encountered. Developed all the "knowledge, skills, and insights" that might be expected from such an experience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
For a future iteration of this course, I would recommend reading less of Vol II and more of Vol V  particularly The Prisoner!! 
I felt like the student-led passage discussions that began happening in the second half of the semester were really grounding. The trouble with reading so much Proust is that sometimes I feel myself getting lost in the weeds, forgetting events, place names, characters, etc., so close passage readings were always the most illuminating for me. I would recommend more of those!

There were no striking weaknesses of the course. Class sessions often depended on student engagement so if you aren't prepared you may not enjoy certain sessions but this is easily avoided by keeping up with reading.
Co-teaching is great. Letting students suggest passages to suggest would be nice.
Professors Bloch and Saint-Amand are wise, charming, and very generous. The reading was incredible, and class time was always a delight.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
The opportunity to spend a semester on Proust is priceless. It will offer you a lifetime of ideas. 
That being said, reading Proust can also be frustrating, confusing, boring, alienating. (But then a sentence of Proust will stop you in your tracks...) 
Take it if you've read a little of Proust and know you want to read a lot more.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in French, literature, modernism, or just encountering new ways of thinking in general. I would caution, however, that it involves a lot of reading. The written assignments are not too heavy.
I'd greatly recommend this class to anyone who loves Proust, literature, the humanities or wants to try a deep-dive into a single great work.
Yesbut make sure you enjoy Proust.

Absolutely. Reading Proust is (in my own limited experience--but also that of many others with much greater amounts of experience) one of the best ways to spend the time of one's life. And it's probably best to start with others, and in a classroom environment--this one in particular.
